block.p: Iranian Leader Speaks Out Against Islamic Extremists President Mohammad Khatami branded Osama bin Laden's version of Islam extremist and said it did not represent the majority of the world's 1.2 billion Muslims. He also hinted that Iran might eventually be prepared to recognize Israel.

Bush to Open U.N. Gathering The General Assembly, which begins its annual meeting under heavy security in New York today, will focus on the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath. President Bush will address the opening. Preliminary debate set the tone for the session with denunciations of the terror attacks as well as calls for tolerance.

Climate Treaty Talks in Morocco Delegates from 164 countries worked late to resolve lingering disputes over the Kyoto Protocol.

Israeli Minister Flees Home Officials confirmed that an Israeli cabinet minister and his family had left their home in an Israeli town near the West Bank over concern that he might be an assassination target.

Religious Crackdown in China The top United Nations human rights official expressed concern that the campaign against terrorism had given license to Beijing to intensify a crackdown on Muslims and the banned Falun Gong spiritual sect.

Emergency Aid in Zimbabwe The World Food Program said it would begin providing emergency food to more than half a million people in Zimbabwe afflicted by a food shortage caused by a convergence of political and natural problems.
Students Kidnapped in Burundi Military officials said Hutu rebels in northern Burundi kidnapped hundreds of high school students just days after more than 80 children were taken hostage in the east.

Social Security Panel Plans To Offer Array of Choices The co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Richard D. Parsons, said that rather than offer one proposal they would present several options for achieving the Bush administration's goal of creating personal investment accounts within the retirement system.

Action to Break Up District The New York state education commissioner moved to dissolve the troubled Roosevelt School District and disperse its 3,000 students among other districts in Nassau County. But he also encouraged the State Legislature to forestall the move by approving the removal of the district's board and by increasing state financing of the district.

Ruling on Preferences to Stand The University of Georgia will not fight a federal appellate ruling voiding an admissions policy that gave extra points to minority applicants. Rather, regents said, the university will seek to promote diversity in other ways. The decision makes a University of Michigan affirmative action action case the likely candidate for Supreme Court review on the issue.

Kerik Decides to Leave When Giuliani Departs Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said he would leave at the end of Mayor Giuliani's term, Dec. 31. A name frequently mentioned as a possible successor is Mayor-elect Bloomberg's principal adviser on criminal justice matters, Raymond W. Kelly, who was Mayor David N. Dinkins's commissioner in 1992 and 1993.
Mr. Bloomberg met with Mr. Dinkins and the labor leader Dennis Rivera and said Nathan Leventhal, a former Koch aide who also led Mr. Dinkins's transition team, would lead his.
A Phone Bill but No Service Verizon has continued to charge a number of residential and commercial telephone customers whose phone service still has not been restored since the Sept. 11 attack.

Girl Is Kidnapped, Then Freed Anna Cardelfe, 6, whose family left their Lower Manhattan apartment after the Sept. 11 terror attack, was found apparently unharmed a day after she was abducted from her front yard in Spring Lake, N.J.

The Sotheby's Trial Opens Federal prosecutors accused A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's auction house, of secretly meeting with his counterpart at Christie's to stifle their customers' ability to bargain between them.
Enron Agrees to Takeover Enron, the world's largest energy trading company, agreed to be acquired by a rival, Dynegy, for about $9 billion in stock and the assumption of $13 billion in debt.

Wholesale Prices Tumble The Producer Price Index posted its biggest decline ever last month as energy costs fell by the largest amount since 1989 and automakers turned to cut-rate financing to lure buyers. The October decline of 1.6 percent was about four times what had been forecast and more than reversed back-to-back gains of 0.4 percent in August and September.

Blue Chips Rebound The Dow closed up 20.48 points, at 9,608.00 -- just above its close of 9,605.51 on Sept. 10, the day before the terror attacks. The S.& P. 500 rose 1.77 points, to 1,120.31, and the Nasdaq gained 0.71 points, to 1,828.48. Both indexes surpassed preattack levels last month. For the week, the Nasdaq gained 4.7 percent, and the Dow and the S.& P. each advanced nearly 3.1 percent.
